steps.dialogue: Look at this square. It's divided into 4 equal parts, and 1 part is shaded.
Which unit fraction shows the shaded part?

step.dialogue: Not quite. Count the total number of equal parts in the square.
[event:pulse_all_sections]Let's think about this together. Count all the parts in the square, then see how many are shaded. That tells you the fraction.

[event:count_sections_sequentially][event:highlight_shaded_vs_total]Here, I'll walk you through this. Let's count all the parts: 1, 2, 3, 4. That's 4 total parts. Now count the shaded parts: just 1. So we have 1 out of 4, which is 1/4. See how that works?

on_correct.dialogue: Exactly right! One out of four equal parts is one-fourth.

@metadata.goal: The student can express equal parts using unit fraction notation

steps.dialogue: Here's a rectangle divided into 4 equal parts. One part is shaded.
Which fraction matches the shaded part?

step.dialogue: Look at the shaded part and count the total parts.

events.name: highlight_shaded_section
events.description: The shaded section pulses to draw attention

step.dialogue: [event:highlight_shaded_section]You're working on it. Count how many parts are shaded, then count how many parts total. That gives you the fraction.

events.name: count_shaded_then_total
events.description: Animated counting overlay: first highlights and labels the 1 shaded section, then sequentially counts and labels all 4 sections (1, 2, 3, 4)

events.name: show_fraction_mapping
events.description: Annotation appears showing '1 shaded' with arrow to numerator and '4 total' with arrow to denominator, forming 1/4

step.dialogue: [event:count_shaded_then_total][event:show_fraction_mapping]Let me show you how this works. Count the shaded parts - that's 1. Count all the parts - that's 4 total. So we have 1 out of 4 parts shaded, which is [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction]. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: That's it! You matched the shaded part to [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction].

@metadata.goal: The student can count the total number of equal parts in a whole

steps.dialogue: Here's a rectangle bar divided into equal parts.
Count all the equal parts in this whole bar.

prompt.text: How many equal parts are there?

step.dialogue: Count the sections in the bar carefully.

events.name: pulse_sections_sequential
events.description: Each section of the bar pulses in sequence from left to right to guide counting

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_sections_sequential]You're working on it. Look at each section in the bar. Count them one by one from left to right.

events.name: count_sections_with_labels
events.description: Animated counting demonstration with numbers 1, 2, 3, 4 appearing sequentially above each section as they are highlighted

step.dialogue: [event:count_sections_with_labels]Let's count together. Watch as I point to each section: one, two, three, four. See? There are four equal parts in this whole bar. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: That's right! Four equal parts make up the whole.

@metadata.goal: The student can identify and maintain the whole when working with unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Here are three rectangle bars. Each one started as the same size, divided into 4 equal parts.
Some bars have missing pieces. Which bar shows one whole—all the parts together?

prompt.text: Click the bar that shows one whole

step.dialogue: Check which bar has all its parts together.

events.name: pulse_sections
events.description: All four sections of Bar A pulse to show completeness

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_sections]You're working on it. The whole means all parts are there. Count how many parts each bar has—we started with 4.

events.name: show_missing_parts_c
events.description: Ghosted outlines appear showing the 3 missing parts of Bar C

events.name: show_missing_parts_b
events.description: Ghosted outlines appear showing the 2 missing parts of Bar B

events.name: highlight_complete
events.description: Bar A glows to indicate it has all parts present

step.dialogue: [event:show_missing_parts_c][event:show_missing_parts_b][event:highlight_complete]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. We started with 4 equal parts. Bar C has only 1 part—missing 3. Bar B has 2 parts—missing 2. Bar A has all 4 parts together. That's the whole. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: That's it. Bar A has all four parts—that's the whole.

@metadata.goal: The student can compare sizes of unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Here are two rectangle bars. The top bar is divided into 3 equal parts with one shaded. The bottom bar is divided into 6 equal parts with one shaded.
Look at the shaded parts. Which fraction is larger?

step.dialogue: Look at the actual size of the shaded parts.

events.name: pulse_shaded
events.description: The shaded sections in both bars pulse to draw attention

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_shaded]You're working on it. Compare the shaded sections - which one takes up more space in its bar?

events.name: measure_shaded_section
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement of the shaded sections in both bars

events.name: size_comparison_highlight
events.description: Visual comparison showing the top bar's shaded section is larger

step.dialogue: [event:measure_shaded_section][event:size_comparison_highlight]This can be tricky, so let's work through it together. Look at the top bar - it's divided into 3 parts, so each part is pretty big. The bottom bar is divided into 6 parts, so each part is much smaller. The shaded part in the top bar ([fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction]) takes up more space than the shaded part in the bottom bar ([fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction]). So [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction] is larger. See how that works?

on_correct.dialogue: That's right. When the whole is divided into fewer parts, each piece is larger.

@metadata.goal: The student can apply partitioning strategies and recognize patterns with equal parts

steps.dialogue: Here's a bar already divided into 2 equal parts. You can see the line in the middle.
Now divide it further to make 4 equal parts. Click once in the center of each half.

step.dialogue: Check your spacing - all parts should be equal.

events.name: highlight_midpoints
events.description: Midpoint of each half pulses to show where to click

step.dialogue: [event:highlight_midpoints]You're working on it. We need 4 equal parts total. Try clicking in the center of each half to divide them evenly.

events.name: show_subdivision_sequence
events.description: Animated demonstration showing cursor clicking at midpoint of first half, then midpoint of second half, with resulting 4 equal sections highlighted

events.name: measure_sections_equal
events.description: Measurement lines appear showing all 4 sections are equal width

step.dialogue: [event:show_subdivision_sequence][event:measure_sections_equal]This can be tricky, so let's do it together. We start with 2 parts. To make 4 equal parts, click right here in the center of this half, then here in the center of the other half. See? Now we have 4 equal parts. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: That's it! You doubled the parts from 2 to 4.

@metadata.goal: The student can understand that all parts must be equal for unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Here's a bar divided into 4 parts. Look closely at the size of each part.
Can this bar represent [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction]? Think about what makes a fraction work.

step.dialogue: Look at the size of each part carefully.

events.name: highlight_sections_sequential
events.description: Each section of bar_1 highlights in sequence to draw attention to size differences

step.dialogue: [event:highlight_sections_sequential]You're working on it. For fractions to work, all parts must be exactly the same size. Check if these parts match.

events.name: measure_sections_unequal
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines highlighting size differences between sections

events.name: label_unequal_parts
events.description: Labels appear showing different widths for each section

step.dialogue: [event:measure_sections_unequal][event:label_unequal_parts]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. For a bar to show [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction], we need 4 equal parts. Watch as I measure each section. See how this part is bigger than that part? When parts aren't equal, we can't use fractions. The answer is False. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: Exactly right. All parts must be equal to show a fraction.
